name: They Said It in the Movies - Part 1 Online Quiz | Movies | 10 Questions

questions.text:
Two desperadoes are teetering on the edge of a ravine. The only escape route from their pursuers is to leap into the chasm-
Butch: "Then you jump first." 
Sundance: "No, I said." 
Butch: "What's the matter with you?" 
Sundance: "I can't ______."
What word is missing?
questions.explanation:
swim.

	These lines come from "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid".This 1969 movie starred Paul Newman as Butch and Robert Redford as Sundance.Steve McQueen was originally picked to play Sundance. But there was disagreement over star's billing and the producers then offered the role to Robert Redford."Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" collected four Academy Awards.

questions.text:
Benjamin Braddock is at the home of his father's business partner Mr Robinson. Much to Benjamin's discomfort he is alone in the house with Mrs Robinson...
Ben: "For god's sake, Mrs. Robinson. Here we are. You got me into your house. You give me a drink. You... put on music. Now you start opening up your personal life to me and tell me your husband won't be home for hours." 
Mrs. Robinson: "So?" 
Ben: "Mrs. Robinson, you're trying to ______ me... Aren't you?"
questions.explanation:
seduce.

	This 1967 movie "The Graduate" starred Dustin Hoffman as Benjamin Braddock and Anne Bancroft as the seductress, Mrs. Robinson.Up and coming young actor Dustin Hoffman was paid just $17,000 for the role of Ben and claimed unemployment when filming ended."The Graduate" won an Oscar for its Director, Mike Nichols.

questions.text:
At a moment of crisis aboard the spacecraft Jim sends the following message-
"Houston, we have a ______." 
Complete this phrase from the movie "Apollo 13".
questions.explanation:
problem.

	This quote from "Apollo 13" was also the tagline for this 1995 movie, starring Tom Hanks as Jim Lovell.The cast and crew flew in NASA's KC-135 airplane to achieve real weightlessness for scenes in the movie. They flew several hundred arcs in the KC-135, nicknamed the "Vomit Comet", each of which gave them 23 seconds of zero gravity.

questions.text:
Nazi businessman Oskar (Oscar) Schindler meets a new recruit at his factory in occupied Poland-
Itzhak Stern: "I'm required to tell you by law... I'm a Jew." 
Oscar Schindler: "Well, I'm a ______. So there we are."
questions.explanation:
German.

	The movie starred Liam Neeson as Oskar Schindler and Ben Kingsley as Itzhak Stern. "Schindler's List", based on the real World War II exploits of Oskar Schindler, was released in 1993. Schindler is credited with saving the lives of more than a thousand Jews. He died in 1974 and was buried in Israel. Director Steven Spielberg took no fee for the movie because he felt it would be "blood money".

questions.text:
Boxer Terry has his hopes of being a prize-fighter crushed-
Terry Malloy: "You don't understand. I coulda' had class. I coulda' been a ______."
Can you complete this famous line from "On the Waterfront"?
questions.explanation:
contender.

	Terry Malloy was played by Marlon Brando in this 1954 favourite."On the Waterfront" won eight Academy Awards one of which was for Brando and another for Eva Marie Saint (Actress in a Supporting Role).The Director Elia Kazan wanted Frank Sinatra to play the lead role, but Producer Sam Spiegel preferred Brando's star quality.

questions.text:
The son of Mafia boss Don Vito Corleone explains his father's uniquely persuasive method of negotiation;
Michael Corleone: "My father made him an offer he couldn't ______." 
Kay Adams: "What was that?" 
Michael Corleone: "Luca Brasi, held a gun to his head, and my father assured him, that either his brain or his signature would be on the contract."
questions.explanation:
refuse.

	Al Pacino starred as Michael Corleone and Diane Keaton as Kay Adams in "The Godfather". This 1973 movie won three Academy Awards. Francis Ford Coppola's sister, who plays Connie Corleone in the movie, is also the aunt of Nicholas Cage.

questions.text:
The following phrase appeared several times in this famous 1980s Science-fiction movie.
E.T. "______ home." 
What method of communication was E.T. to use?
questions.explanation:
phone.

	"E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial" collected four Academy Awards, for music, sound, sound effects and visual effects.The movie had a mixed reception in Sweden where youngsters under eleven-years-old were banned from seeing it because it portrayed disobedient children.

questions.text:
At the time of the American Civil War a self-indulgent woman fails to reveal her true feelings to the man she loves.
Scarlett O'Hara: "Rhett... If you go ... where shall I go? What shall I do?" 
Rhett Butler: "Frankly, my dear, I don't give a ______."
questions.explanation:
damn.

	This classic line from the movie "Gone With the Wind" was uttered by  Rhett Butler, played by Clark Gable, to Scarlett O'Hara, played by Vivien Leigh.Gable was not keen to play the role, but was offered a big financial inducement. He needed the money to enable him to divorce his wife so that he could marry his new love Carole Lombard.The horse ridden in the movie by Gerald O'Hara also appeared on TV as the Lone Ranger's mount Silver.

questions.text:
Three city slickers Mitch, Ed and Phil, go on a cattle-driving holiday. 
The discussion gets around to relationships with the opposite sex and one of the trio offers his personal view. 
Mitch: "Women need a reason for having sex, men just need a ______."
questions.explanation:
place.

	"City Slickers" starred Billy Crystal as Mitch and Jack Palance as Curly.Jack Palance won a Best Supporting Actor Oscar for his role in this 1991 movie.

questions.text:
Rick Blaine runs a nightclub in World War II Casablanca. Out of the blue ex-girlfriend, Ilsa, walks into the bar, rekindling memories of their romance and "their tune".
Ilsa Lund: "Play it once, _____. For old times' sake."
Pianist: "I don't know what you mean, Miss 'Elsa' (Ilsa)."
Ilsa Lund: "Play it, _____. Play "As Time Goes By.""
What is the pianist's name?
questions.explanation:
Sam.

	These lines come from the classic 1942 movie "Casablanca". Humphrey Bogart starred as Richard 'Rick' Blaine and Ingrid Bergman  as Ilsa Lund Laszlo.The pianist Sam was played by Dooley Wilson."Casablanca" was originally to be a medium budget movie called "Everybody Goes to Rick's" starring Ronald Reagan and Ann Sheridan.Casablanca notched up three Academy Awards.
